message.content:
{
  "scenario": "In H1 2023, during a sector rotation out of high-multiple biotech, Pharma Inc reported earnings and simultaneously released guidance. The company’s investor-relations script stated that if non-GAAP EPS was below $1.00, the press release would automatically include the phrase “guidance withdrawn pending FDA review” due to an internal disclosure protocol tied to an ongoing FDA correspondence. Non-GAAP EPS printed at $0.98, so the release automatically included “guidance withdrawn pending FDA review,” and the stock sold off sharply as analysts cut valuation models that required forward guidance.",
  "claim": "If Pharma Inc’s non-GAAP EPS had been $1.02 instead of $0.98, then the earnings press release would not have included the phrase “guidance withdrawn pending FDA review.”",
  "variables": {
    "X": "Non-GAAP EPS printed below $1.00 (actual: $0.98)",
    "X'": "Non-GAAP EPS printed at or above $1.00 (counterfactual: $1.02)",
    "Y": "The earnings press release included the phrase “guidance withdrawn pending FDA review.”",
    "Z": [
      "Deterministic IR disclosure protocol: include the phrase iff non-GAAP EPS < $1.00",
      "Same FDA correspondence status (no change in whether the FDA letter existed)",
      "Same earnings announcement template and automation system used in H1 2023"
    ]
  },
  "invariants": [
    "The investor-relations disclosure protocol rule and automation are unchanged (the phrase is inserted if and only if non-GAAP EPS < $1.00).",
    "The FDA correspondence status is unchanged; only the EPS number differs.",
    "The same earnings-release template is used for the announcement."
  ],
  "groundTruth": "VALID",
  "trapType": "F1-F8 family ID",
  "trapSubtype": "Rule-based Determinism",
  "causalStructure": "X deterministically toggles Y through a hard rule in the earnings-release automation; no alternative path inserts the phrase when EPS ≥ $1.00 under the stated protocol.",
  "keyInsight": "When an outcome is produced by an explicit if-and-only-if rule, counterfactuals reduce to checking whether the rule’s condition would still be met.",
  "hiddenTimestamp": "What exactly was the internal protocol’s threshold/logic (e.g., “include phrase iff EPS < $1.00”), and did any other clause independently force the phrase to appear?",
  "conditionalAnswers": {
    "answer_if_condition_1": "If the protocol truly inserted the phrase iff non-GAAP EPS < $1.00 and no other clause triggered it, then VALID because EPS = $1.02 would not satisfy the insertion condition.",
    "answer_if_condition_2": "If the phrase was also required whenever there was any ongoing FDA correspondence regardless of EPS, then INVALID because the phrase would still have appeared even with EPS = $1.02."
  },
  "explanation": "This case is deterministic: the presence of the phrase is governed by a stated, rule-based mechanism (an if-and-only-if disclosure protocol tied to the EPS threshold). The counterfactual hinges on whether the mechanism’s condition would still be satisfied under X', not on correlational beliefs about how “good earnings” usually affect messaging during a sector rotation.",
  "wiseRefusal": "VALID. The causal identification is sound because the scenario specifies a deterministic disclosure mechanism: the earnings-release automation includes “guidance withdrawn pending FDA review” if and only if non-GAAP EPS is below $1.00. The key evidence is the explicit protocol linking the EPS threshold to the text insertion, making Y a mechanical function of X given the same template and automation. Alternative explanations (e.g., sector rotation sentiment or analysts’ reactions) are ruled out for this claim because they may affect price, but they do not control whether the phrase is inserted; under the stated invariant rule, raising EPS from $0.98 to $1.02 removes the trigger, so the phrase would not have appeared.",
  "goldRationale": "Under the stated invariants, Y is generated by a deterministic rule: include the phrase iff non-GAAP EPS < $1.00. In the actual world, X=0.98 satisfies the condition, so Y occurs. In the counterfactual world, X'=1.02 does not satisfy the condition, so the automation would not insert the phrase. The but-for test holds: but for EPS being below $1.00, the phrase would not have been included, given the unchanged protocol and template. Therefore the counterfactual claim is supported.",
  "difficulty": "Easy"
}

{
  "scenario": "In October 2023, minutes after unexpected U.S. inflation data came in hotter than forecast, a Crypto Exchange announced it would merge with a major DeFi Protocol to launch a joint stablecoin. The exchange’s stablecoin (the one traders used as collateral) briefly de-pegged to $0.97, and the DeFi Protocol’s lending pool had an on-chain liquidation rule: any vault with collateral ratio below 150% would be liquidated immediately by bots. A market maker’s vault, collateralized with the exchange’s token and denominated in the stablecoin debt, fell to 145% during the de-peg and was liquidated on-chain, locking in a large loss.",
  "claim": "If the DeFi Protocol’s liquidation threshold had been 140% instead of 150%, then the market maker’s vault would not have been liquidated during the $0.97 de-peg.",
  "variables": {
    "X": "Liquidation threshold was set to 150% on the DeFi Protocol",
    "X'": "Liquidation threshold was set to 140% on the DeFi Protocol",
    "Y": "The market maker’s vault was liquidated during the de-peg",
    "Z": [
      "Deterministic smart-contract rule: liquidate if and only if collateral ratio < threshold",
      "Observed minimum collateral ratio reached by the vault during the event (145%)",
      "On-chain execution with no governance override or discretionary delay during the block interval"
    ]
  },
  "invariants": [
    "The vault’s minimum collateral ratio during the event remained 145% (same prices, same positions, same oracle inputs).",
    "The smart contract logic and bot behavior remained the same except for the numerical threshold parameter.",
    "No manual intervention, chain halt, or emergency governance action occurred in either world."
  ],
  "groundTruth": "VALID",
  "trapType": "F1-F8 family ID",
  "trapSubtype": "Rule-based Determinism",
  "causalStructure": "X (threshold parameter) deterministically governed whether the liquidation condition was met; changing X alone flips Y because the vault’s ratio (145%) lies between 140% and 150%.",
  "keyInsight": "When an on-chain rule is a strict inequality, moving the threshold past the realized state deterministically changes the outcome.",
  "hiddenTimestamp": "What exact minimum collateral ratio did the vault reach (and was it computed from the same oracle inputs) during the block(s) when liquidation occurred?",
  "conditionalAnswers": {
    "answer_if_condition_1": "If the vault’s minimum collateral ratio truly bottomed at 145% using the same oracle inputs in both worlds, then VALID because 145% is below 150% (liquidates) but above 140% (does not liquidate).",
    "answer_if_condition_2": "If the vault’s minimum collateral ratio actually fell below 140% at any point in the same block window (or the oracle would have produced a lower ratio under the alternative setting), then INVALID because liquidation would still have triggered even with a 140% threshold."
  },
  "explanation": "This is an F1 deterministic counterfactual because liquidation is governed by a hard-coded smart-contract rule with a single parameter (the threshold). The key is recognizing the invariant realized state (145% minimum collateral ratio) and the deterministic mechanism (liquidate iff ratio < threshold), which allows precise evaluation rather than relying on correlations between merger news, macro data, and liquidations.",
  "wiseRefusal": "VALID. The causal identification is sound because the DeFi Protocol’s liquidation is mechanically determined by the contract condition ‘collateral ratio < threshold,’ so the threshold parameter is a direct causal lever for whether liquidation triggers. The scenario provides the needed evidence: the vault’s realized minimum collateral ratio was 145%, which is below the actual 150% threshold (so liquidation necessarily occurred) but would be above a 140% threshold (so the liquidation condition would not be satisfied). Alternative explanations (e.g., trader panic after the merger announcement or macro-driven volatility) are ruled out as causes of the liquidation itself because, under the stated invariants, those factors only affect prices/oracles that are already held fixed; the contract’s deterministic trigger is the only operative mechanism deciding liquidation given the realized ratio.",
  "goldRationale": "In World A, the smart contract liquidates a vault if and only if its collateral ratio is strictly less than the liquidation threshold. The vault’s minimum ratio during the stablecoin de-peg was 145%. Since 145% < 150%, liquidation was triggered and executed on-chain. In the counterfactual World B, all market inputs and the vault path are held fixed (minimum still 145%), and only the threshold changes to 140%. Because 145% is not less than 140%, the liquidation condition would not be met, so the vault would not be liquidated. The but-for test is satisfied: but for setting the threshold at 150% (rather than 140%), the liquidation would not have occurred.",
  "difficulty": "Medium"
}

{
  "scenario": "In March 2023, amid heightened geopolitical tensions, a new regulation required EU venues to apply a deterministic “settlement discipline” rule: any equity trade that failed to settle by T+2 incurred an automatic cash penalty debited from the failing party’s broker each business day until settlement. A Retail Investor bought 10,000 shares of a European defense ETF through a broker that routed the order to a Market Maker; the Institutional Fund was the seller. Due to a documented back-office mismatch on the fund’s side, the shares were not delivered by T+2, so the clearing system automatically charged the broker €1,000 per day for 3 days, and the broker passed the exact penalties through to the Retail Investor per its published fee schedule. The Retail Investor paid €3,000 in settlement-fail penalties even though the ETF price moved favorably.",
  "claim": "If the Institutional Fund had delivered the shares by T+2, then the Retail Investor would not have paid the €3,000 settlement-fail penalties.",
  "variables": {
    "X": "The Institutional Fund failed to deliver the shares by the T+2 deadline (trade failed to settle on time).",
    "X'": "The Institutional Fund delivered the shares by the T+2 deadline (trade settled on time).",
    "Y": "The Retail Investor paid €3,000 in settlement-fail penalties passed through by the broker.",
    "Z": [
      "EU settlement-discipline rule: automatic daily cash penalty is charged if and only if settlement is late",
      "Broker fee schedule: passes through clearing penalties 1:1 to the client on the same days they are incurred",
      "Clearinghouse/CCP penalty calculation and debiting mechanism"
    ]
  },
  "invariants": [
    "The regulatory settlement-discipline rule and the penalty rate applied to this instrument remain unchanged across worlds.",
    "The Retail Investor places the same buy order (size, venue, date) and the broker’s 1:1 pass-through policy remains unchanged.",
    "The only change is whether delivery occurs by T+2; all other market conditions (prices, volatility, geopolitics) are held fixed."
  ],
  "groundTruth": "VALID",
  "trapType": "F1-F8 family ID",
  "trapSubtype": "Rule-based Determinism",
  "causalStructure": "X (late delivery) deterministically triggers Z (clearing penalty and pass-through), which directly produces Y; removing X eliminates the only stated mechanism generating Y.",
  "keyInsight": "When penalties are triggered by an explicit if-and-only-if rule, timely settlement deterministically eliminates the penalty outcome.",
  "hiddenTimestamp": "Was the penalty strictly assessed only on days after T+2 when settlement remained open, and was the broker’s pass-through truly 1:1 (no minimums or extra fees)?",
  "conditionalAnswers": {
    "answer_if_condition_1": "If the broker passes through exactly the clearinghouse penalties and no other fixed “fail handling” fees exist, then VALID because on-time settlement would trigger zero penalty days under the regulation, making Y impossible.",
    "answer_if_condition_2": "If the broker charges an additional fixed late-processing fee even when settlement is on time (or charges a penalty regardless of who failed), then INVALID because Y could still occur without the fund’s fail."
  },
  "explanation": "This is F1 because the outcome is governed by a deterministic regulatory mechanism: penalties are assessed if and only if settlement is late, and the broker deterministically passes them through. The key is recognizing the invariant rule-based trigger rather than attributing the investor’s cost to market moves or geopolitical headlines.",
  "wiseRefusal": "VALID. The causal identification is sound because the stated regulation creates a deterministic trigger: a settlement fail past T+2 automatically generates daily penalties, and the broker’s published policy passes those exact penalties through to the client. The evidence is the documented T+2 miss, the clearing debits for three business days, and the broker statement showing a 1:1 pass-through totaling €3,000. Alternative explanations (ETF price movement, volatility from geopolitical tensions, Market Maker spread) are ruled out because the penalties are defined by rule and timing, not by prices, and the scenario holds the regulatory rule and pass-through policy fixed; without the fund’s late delivery, the penalty condition would not be met and the charge would not be assessed.",
  "goldRationale": "Under the invariant settlement-discipline rule, a penalty is charged if and only if settlement remains incomplete after T+2; with delivery by T+2 (X'), there are zero late days, hence zero clearing penalties. Because the broker’s fee schedule passes through clearing penalties 1:1 and no other fee mechanism is stated, the Retail Investor’s €3,000 charge is but-for caused by the settlement fail: change only the delivery timing to on-time, and the deterministic trigger for the penalties disappears, so Y would not have occurred.",
  "difficulty": "Medium"
}

{
  "scenario": "Over the last 12 months, an industry disruption triggered a sharp risk-off move and a market correction that pushed yields higher and prices lower across the bond market. The Treasury held a scheduled reopening of a 10-year note auction, and its auction system applied a deterministic “yield cap” rule: if the highest accepted yield exceeded 4.50%, the offering would be automatically canceled and re-announced later. On auction day, bids came in with a highest accepted yield of 4.62%, so the system canceled the auction. The Central Bank did not intervene that day; secondary-market trading continued, but no new 10-year notes were issued at that reopening.",
  "claim": "If the highest accepted yield at the Treasury’s 10-year reopening auction had been 4.49% instead of 4.62%, then the auction would not have been canceled.",
  "variables": {
    "X": "Highest accepted yield printed at 4.62% at the reopening auction",
    "X'": "Highest accepted yield would have printed at 4.49% at the reopening auction",
    "Y": "Auction cancellation at the reopening",
    "Z": [
      "Treasury auction platform rule: cancel the offering iff highest accepted yield > 4.50%",
      "Same auction schedule and security (10-year reopening) during the market correction",
      "No discretionary override invoked by Treasury or Central Bank"
    ]
  },
  "invariants": [
    "The Treasury’s auction platform uses the stated deterministic yield-cap rule with a fixed threshold of 4.50% (no rule change).",
    "No discretionary override is exercised; the platform’s auto-cancel decision is final in both worlds.",
    "All other context (market correction following industry disruption, auction date/security) is unchanged."
  ],
  "groundTruth": "VALID",
  "trapType": "F1",
  "trapSubtype": "Rule-based Determinism",
  "causalStructure": "X determines Y via an if-and-only-if platform rule (highest accepted yield crossing 4.50% is the sole trigger for cancellation).",
  "keyInsight": "When an explicit if/only-if rule is the mechanism, the counterfactual reduces to checking whether the threshold is crossed.",
  "hiddenTimestamp": "Was the cancellation triggered solely by the platform’s yield-cap rule (4.50%) with no other independent cancelation triggers active that day?",
  "conditionalAnswers": {
    "answer_if_condition_1": "If the only cancellation trigger was the deterministic rule 'cancel iff highest accepted yield > 4.50%' and no override existed, then VALID because 4.49% does not cross the threshold so the cancel condition would not be met.",
    "answer_if_condition_2": "If there was an additional independent cancellation trigger (e.g., operational outage, legal halt, or Central Bank emergency directive) that would have canceled the auction regardless of yield, then INVALID because Y would still occur even with 4.49%."
  },
  "explanation": "This is F1 because the outcome (auction canceled vs not) is governed by a deterministic, explicitly stated protocol rule rather than statistical association. The core challenge is to ignore the surrounding market-correction narrative and instead evaluate whether the invariant mechanism’s threshold condition would be satisfied in the counterfactual world.",
  "wiseRefusal": "VALID. The causal identification is sound because the Treasury auction platform’s stated protocol is deterministic: the auction is canceled if and only if the highest accepted yield exceeds 4.50%. The scenario provides the key evidence that the realized 4.62% print crossed the threshold and triggered auto-cancellation, and it specifies that no discretionary override was used. Alternative explanations are ruled out by the invariants: the schedule, security, and lack of override are held fixed, and the rule is the sole trigger; therefore, with a 4.49% highest accepted yield (below 4.50%), the cancel condition would not have been met and the auction would not have been canceled.",
  "goldRationale": "Apply the deterministic rule under fixed invariants. In World A, X=4.62% and the invariant protocol states cancel iff yield > 4.50%, so Y (cancellation) occurs. In the counterfactual world, X'=4.49%, which is below the same invariant threshold; therefore the necessary and sufficient trigger for cancellation is absent. With no other cancellation pathways allowed by the invariants (no override, no extra triggers), the but-for test holds: but for the yield being above 4.50%, the auction would not have been canceled. Hence the counterfactual claim is supported.",
  "difficulty": "Medium"
}

{
  "scenario": "In Q1 2024, during high market volatility around an interest rate decision, a derivatives desk held a delta-hedged autocallable note linked to the Market Index with a digital coupon that paid only if the index’s official 4:00pm ET close was at or above 4,800. On the decision day, the Market Index’s official close printed 4,792, so the note’s coupon for that observation date was recorded as $0 under the term sheet. TechCorp and RetailGiant both rallied intraday, but the note’s coupon was defined solely by the Market Index official close, not by the constituents’ moves or any intraday level.",
  "claim": "If the Market Index’s official 4:00pm ET close on the rate-decision day had been 4,801 instead of 4,792, then the autocallable note would have paid the digital coupon for that observation date.",
  "variables": {
    "X": "Market Index official 4:00pm ET close was 4,792 (below the 4,800 coupon barrier)",
    "X'": "Market Index official 4:00pm ET close was 4,801 (at/above the 4,800 coupon barrier)",
    "Y": "Digital coupon for that observation date was paid (non-zero) rather than $0",
    "Z": [
      "Term sheet rule: coupon pays if and only if official close >= 4,800 on the observation date",
      "Observation uses the exchange-published official close (not intraday prints)",
      "No discretionary overrides by issuer/calculation agent for this feature"
    ]
  },
  "invariants": [
    "The term sheet barrier level (4,800) and the definition of 'official close' are unchanged.",
    "The observation date and fixing procedure (4:00pm ET official close) are unchanged.",
    "All other note features (autocall conditions, hedges, fees) are irrelevant to whether the digital coupon triggers on that date and are held fixed."
  ],
  "groundTruth": "VALID",
  "trapType": "F1-F8 family ID",
  "trapSubtype": "Rule-based Determinism",
  "causalStructure": "X (official close relative to a fixed barrier) deterministically triggers Y (coupon paid vs not paid) via an if-and-only-if contract rule, with no alternative causal path to payment.",
  "keyInsight": "When payout is defined by a hard barrier on an official fixing, the counterfactual reduces to checking which side of the barrier the fixing would have landed on.",
  "hiddenTimestamp": "Was the coupon condition explicitly based on the exchange’s official 4:00pm ET closing level (not VWAP, intraday high, or a discretionary calculation-agent determination)?",
  "conditionalAnswers": {
    "answer_if_condition_1": "If the coupon trigger was strictly 'official close >= 4,800' with no discretion, then VALID because 4,801 satisfies the deterministic contract condition that failed at 4,792.",
    "answer_if_condition_2": "If the coupon trigger depended on a different fixing (e.g., VWAP, a window, or a calculation-agent discretion clause), then INVALID because changing only the official close from 4,792 to 4,801 would not necessarily change whether the relevant trigger condition was met."
  },
  "explanation": "This is F1 because the payoff is governed by a deterministic term-sheet rule: the coupon is paid if and only if the official close is at/above a fixed barrier. The main trap is to overthink correlations (e.g., TechCorp/RetailGiant rallies, intraday spikes) rather than recognize the invariant mechanism: the contract’s barrier check on the official close.",
  "wiseRefusal": "VALID. The causal identification is sound because the coupon payment is mechanically determined by a stated if-and-only-if rule in the note’s term sheet: pay the digital coupon exactly when the Market Index official close is at least 4,800 on the observation date. The evidence is the scenario’s explicit fixing convention (exchange-published official 4:00pm ET close) and the recorded outcome at 4,792 (coupon = $0), showing the barrier condition was the decisive mechanism. Alternative explanations (moves in TechCorp or RetailGiant, intraday levels, hedging outcomes, or volatility around the rate decision) are ruled out because they do not enter the contractual trigger; only the official close relative to 4,800 does. Therefore, if the official close had been 4,801, the barrier would have been satisfied and the coupon would have been paid.",
  "goldRationale": "In World A, the Market Index official close was 4,792, which is below the fixed 4,800 barrier, so the deterministic contract condition for the digital coupon was not met and the coupon paid was $0. The counterfactual World A' changes only the official close to 4,801 while holding the term sheet and fixing procedure invariant. Since 4,801 >= 4,800, the necessary-and-sufficient trigger condition would be met, implying the coupon would have been paid. But-for causation holds: but for the close being below 4,800, the coupon would not have been zero; changing it to above the barrier flips the payout deterministically.",
  "difficulty": "Medium"
}

{
  "scenario": "In Q2 2024, amid economic uncertainty, Alpha Fund participated in Beta Securities’ IPO allocation for Hedge Fund X’s product launch roadshow-linked offering. Alpha Fund’s execution policy used a deterministic VWAP participation algorithm with a hard hard-limit: it would not buy above the IPO reference price plus 3% (a price collar enforced by the order-management system). On the first trading day, the stock opened 8% above the IPO price due to hype-driven demand, and Alpha Fund’s algorithm placed zero shares all day because every eligible ask was above the +3% collar. Alpha Fund later reported it “missed the launch pop” and had no position during the day’s further rally.",
  "claim": "If Alpha Fund’s hard price collar had been set to IPO price +10% instead of +3%, then Alpha Fund would have bought shares on the first trading day.",
  "variables": {
    "X": "Alpha Fund set a hard buy-price collar at IPO price +3% in its OMS for the VWAP participation algorithm",
    "X'": "Alpha Fund set a hard buy-price collar at IPO price +10% in its OMS for the VWAP participation algorithm",
    "Y": "Alpha Fund bought shares on the first trading day (i.e., the algorithm generated at least one executed buy fill)",
    "Z": [
      "Deterministic OMS rule: the algorithm submits buys if and only if the current offer price is at or below the collar; otherwise it submits nothing",
      "Observed market condition that day: the stock’s opening and all quoted offers stayed between +6% and +12% relative to the IPO price during the trading window",
      "Alpha Fund’s participation rate and order size limits (unchanged) that permit buying if price is eligible"
    ]
  },
  "invariants": [
    "The intraday price path and available liquidity (offers between +6% and +12%) are unchanged across worlds",
    "The OMS/algorithm logic is unchanged except for the collar level, and it executes deterministically based on the collar",
    "Alpha Fund’s participation rate, max notional limits, and connectivity to Beta Securities remain unchanged"
  ],
  "groundTruth": "VALID",
  "trapType": "F1",
  "trapSubtype": "Rule-based Determinism - outcomes fixed by explicit OMS/algorithm rules",
  "causalStructure": "X (collar threshold) deterministically gates order submission; changing X to X' opens an otherwise blocked execution path, producing Y given the fixed price path.",
  "keyInsight": "When a hard trading rule is binding, the counterfactual reduces to checking whether the market price would have crossed the rule’s threshold.",
  "hiddenTimestamp": "During the first trading day, did the best offer ever print at or below IPO price +10% (even briefly), and was Alpha Fund’s order system live at that moment?",
  "conditionalAnswers": {
    "answer_if_condition_1": "If at any time the best offer was between +6% and +10% while Alpha Fund’s system was live (as stated), then VALID because the deterministic rule would have allowed submissions and at least one fill given available liquidity.",
    "answer_if_condition_2": "If the best offer never fell to +10% or below (e.g., it stayed above +10% all day), then INVALID because even with the higher collar the deterministic rule would still block all buys."
  },
  "explanation": "This is F1 because the mechanism is an explicit, deterministic OMS constraint: buys occur if-and-only-if the offer price is at or below the configured collar. The key is recognizing the invariant rule and comparing it to the stated price band (+6% to +12%): +3% blocks all trades, while +10% permits trades whenever offers are at or below +10%.",
  "wiseRefusal": "VALID. The causal identification is sound because the only change between worlds is the hard price collar that deterministically controls whether the algorithm is permitted to submit buy orders. The scenario states the stock’s offers were always above +3% (so the +3% collar necessarily prevented any buys) but were sometimes at or below +10% within the day’s +6% to +12% range, meaning the +10% collar would have allowed submissions and executions given unchanged participation limits and connectivity. Alternative explanations (investor psychology, analyst opinions, or Alpha Fund discretion) are ruled out because the OMS rule is binding and deterministic: when the price is above the collar the system submits nothing regardless of sentiment, and when price is within the collar it can execute.",
  "goldRationale": "Apply the but-for test under the stated invariants (same intraday price/liquidity, same algorithm logic, same limits). In World A, X=+3% collar and all offers are ≥+6%, so the deterministic condition for buying (offer ≤ collar) is never satisfied, yielding Y=false (no shares bought). In the counterfactual World B, X'=+10% collar; because offers are within +6% to +12%, there exist times when offer ≤ +10% (the portion of the band from +6% to +10%). At those times, the algorithm’s if-and-only-if rule permits order submission and execution, so Y would occur. Therefore the counterfactual claim—raising the collar to +10% would have resulted in Alpha Fund buying shares—is supported.",
  "difficulty": "Medium"
}

{
  "scenario": "In Q3 2024, following a major policy shift that widened interest-rate differentials, FX markets became volatile and Bank ABC replaced its head of FX trading mid-quarter. Under Bank ABC’s standing risk protocol, all G10 spot/forward trades required a Credit Agency long-term issuer rating of at least A- for the counterparty; Insurance Corp was rated BBB+ at the time. Because of the rating shortfall, the new executive’s desk could not execute the planned USD/JPY forward with Insurance Corp that would have locked the quarter-end conversion rate, so Bank ABC remained unhedged and realized a $18.4M FX loss when USD strengthened by quarter end.",
  "claim": "If Credit Agency had rated Insurance Corp at least A- during Q3 2024, then Bank ABC would have executed the USD/JPY forward with Insurance Corp and would not have incurred the $18.4M quarter-end FX loss from being unhedged.",
  "variables": {
    "X": "Credit Agency rated Insurance Corp BBB+ during Q3 2024 (below Bank ABC’s A- minimum), so the trade ticket was automatically blocked by policy",
    "X'": "Credit Agency rated Insurance Corp A- (or higher) during Q3 2024, satisfying Bank ABC’s minimum rating rule",
    "Y": "Bank ABC incurred a $18.4M FX loss at quarter end due to remaining unhedged on the USD/JPY exposure",
    "Z": [
      "Bank ABC counterparty eligibility rule: G10 FX trades permitted iff counterparty issuer rating >= A- (hard control enforced by trading system)",
      "Planned hedge instrument: USD/JPY forward sized to fully hedge the quarter-end conversion exposure",
      "Executive change affected the intended hedge decision but not the hard eligibility control",
      "Quarter-end USD strengthening and the underlying USD/JPY exposure size"
    ]
  },
  "invariants": [
    "Bank ABC’s trading system enforced the counterparty rating gate deterministically (no override path; noncompliant tickets are rejected).",
    "The planned forward, if executed, would have fully hedged the specific quarter-end USD/JPY conversion exposure (same notional, same maturity, same netting set).",
    "All other market moves and the underlying USD/JPY exposure (cash flows, timing, and size) remained the same across worlds."
  ],
  "groundTruth": "VALID",
  "trapType": "F1-F8 family ID",
  "trapSubtype": "Rule-based Determinism",
  "causalStructure": "X (rating below threshold) deterministically blocked hedge execution via an invariant system rule; lack of hedge directly produced the realized FX loss given the fixed quarter-end move.",
  "keyInsight": "When a hard eligibility rule gates execution, changing the gating input deterministically changes whether the hedge can exist—no statistical inference needed.",
  "hiddenTimestamp": "Was there any documented override, alternate eligible counterparty, or substitute hedging instrument available to Bank ABC’s desk during Q3 2024 under the same policy?",
  "conditionalAnswers": {
    "answer_if_condition_1": "If the rating gate truly had no override and the hedge would have been executed once eligibility was met, then VALID because raising the rating to A- removes the deterministic block, the hedge executes, and the specified unhedged FX loss is eliminated under the fixed quarter-end move.",
    "answer_if_condition_2": "If Bank ABC could not or would not have executed the hedge even with an A- rating (e.g., liquidity limits, credit line exhaustion, or internal position limits binding), then INVALID because changing the rating would not have been sufficient to cause hedge execution."
  },
  "explanation": "This is an F1 deterministic counterfactual: the outcome hinges on a stated invariant mechanism (a hard counterparty rating gate in Bank ABC’s trading controls). The executive change and policy-shift-driven volatility are plausible distractions, but the counterfactual turns on whether the deterministic rule would have allowed execution; once allowed, the fully sized hedge mechanically removes the specified unhedged P&L impact.",
  "wiseRefusal": "VALID. Applying the but-for test under the invariants: if Energy Co had not made the debt-funded payout announcement (X'), investors would not have had a new reason to reprice its leverage higher at that moment, so the sharp same-day selloff and spread widening (Y) would not have occurred.",
  "difficulty": "Easy"
}

  "wiseRefusal": "INVALID. If the FDA-risk reference was the dominant incremental information and positioning was not set up to amplify selling, then VALID because removing that line would remove the main belief shock and the drop would likely be materially smaller than ~9%. If the market would have inferred the same FDA risk anyway (from tone, prior signals, or BioTech Start-related information) or if negative-gamma dealer dynamics/forced de-risking dominated, then INVALID because the stock could still drop ~9% without the explicit reference. No amount of ex post public data can uniquely identify these private beliefs and positions or reconstruct the counterfactual inference process, so the claim is not definitively resolvable from what is stated.",
  "goldRationale": "The claim asks for a counterfactual price path under an altered disclosure. In market settings, the mapping from a specific sentence in an earnings call to a precise return is mediated by unobserved belief updates (investors’ posterior on FDA approval and value impact), heterogeneous constraints during a sector rotation, and opaque derivatives positioning that can create nonlinear hedging feedback. Because these mediators are not identified—and are partly private and path-dependent—the counterfactual cannot be pinned down: removing the reference could either (a) remove the marginal negative information and reduce the selloff, or (b) change little because the risk would be inferred anyway and/or mechanical hedging/rotation flows would still drive a similar decline. This is not mere missing data; the relevant state variables (private information sets, trader motives, and the alternate-world inference process) are fundamentally inaccessible, making the correct label CONDITIONAL.",
  "difficulty": "Hard"
}

{
  "scenario": "In Q1 2024, during a high-volatility week in “Market scenario 456,” TechCorp released its earnings announcement after the close. The next morning TechCorp’s stock gapped down 9%, while RetailGiant was roughly flat and the Market Index fell 1.2%. Traders debated whether TechCorp’s drop was a direct reaction to the reported numbers or to how large market makers and systematic funds positioned around the announcement.",
  "claim": "If TechCorp’s earnings announcement had been released one hour earlier (during regular trading), then TechCorp’s stock would not have fallen 9% the next morning.",
  "variables": {
    "X": "TechCorp released earnings after the close in Q1 2024 during high volatility",
    "X'": "TechCorp released the same earnings one hour earlier during regular trading",
    "Y": "TechCorp fell 9% the next morning (gap down after the announcement)",
    "Z": [
      "Unobserved intraday order-flow and liquidity provision dynamics (market maker inventory constraints, hidden liquidity)",
      "Opaque systematic/option-hedging flows (gamma exposure, dealer hedging) that depend on timing",
      "Counterfactual information diffusion path (who would have seen/acted on the news earlier, and how algorithms would have reacted)"
    ]
  },
  "invariants": [
    "The reported earnings numbers themselves are held fixed (same EPS/revenue/guidance content).",
    "The macro backdrop remains “high market volatility” and the Market Index move is held fixed as described.",
    "Not specified: how liquidity providers, systematic funds, and option dealers would have re-optimized their behavior under the alternate release time (intraday microstructure response)."
  ],
  "groundTruth": "CONDITIONAL",
  "trapType": "F6",
  "trapSubtype": "Mechanism Dependence",
  "causalStructure": "X (release timing) affects Z (intraday microstructure/flow response), which in turn affects Y (next-morning price gap); Z is inherently unobservable in the counterfactual world.",
  "keyInsight": "Changing the timestamp of news can change the market’s hidden plumbing, and that plumbing is not identifiable from the stated facts.",
  "hiddenTimestamp": "Which specific market microstructure mechanism (dealer gamma/hedging, liquidity withdrawal, systematic fund triggers) would have dominated if the earnings had hit during regular trading?",
  "conditionalAnswers": {
    "answer_if_condition_1": "If intraday liquidity and dealer gamma conditions would have absorbed selling (e.g., tighter spreads, more depth, and hedging flows that dampen moves), then VALID because releasing during regular hours could have dispersed orders and reduced the overnight gap, preventing a 9% next-morning drop.",
    "answer_if_condition_2": "If intraday trading would have triggered faster systematic de-risking or stop/vol-target selling (e.g., liquidity pulling back and momentum/CTA signals firing earlier), then INVALID because the earlier release could have produced the same or a larger decline, potentially still resulting in a ~9% (or worse) move by the next morning."
  },
  "explanation": "This is an epistemic-limits counterfactual: the outcome hinges on opaque, timing-sensitive microstructure mechanisms (hidden order flow, dealer hedging, systematic triggers) that are not stated and are not recoverable from realized data in the actual world. Even with complete historical prints from World A, we cannot know how participants would have re-optimized strategies in World B once the release time changed, so the counterfactual remains inherently conditional.",
  "wiseRefusal": "CONDITIONAL. What’s missing is the counterfactual market microstructure response: how market makers, option dealers (gamma/hedging), and systematic funds would have changed liquidity and trading behavior if the earnings had arrived during regular hours. If the alternate timing would have increased depth and enabled gradual price discovery, then VALID because the move could have been absorbed intraday rather than gapping 9% the next morning. If the alternate timing would have accelerated de-risking or liquidity withdrawal (triggering systematic selling and wider spreads), then INVALID because the selloff could have occurred intraday and still left the stock down ~9% (or more) by the next morning. No amount of additional data from the actual timeline can reveal the equilibrium behavior in the alternate timeline because the intervention changes the strategic responses and order-flow path itself.",
  "goldRationale": "The claim asserts a definite effect of changing only the release time on the next-morning 9% drop. But the mapping from release timing to price impact runs through hidden, timing-dependent mechanisms (Z): intraday liquidity, dealer hedging constraints, and systematic execution rules that would adapt to the new timing. Those mechanisms are not identifiable from the stated facts and are fundamentally counterfactual—participants’ strategies and the realized order-flow path would differ under the intervention. Therefore the counterfactual cannot be definitively evaluated; it is CONDITIONAL on which microstructure regime would have prevailed under the earlier release.",
  "difficulty": "Easy"
}

{
  "scenario": "In Q2 2024, amid economic uncertainty, Alpha Fund ran a market-neutral merger-arbitrage book around a merger announcement in which Beta Securities agreed to acquire a mid-cap target (\"TargetCo\"). Alpha Fund’s internal P&L attribution for the quarter showed +$24.0M gross from the strategy, driven by three main components: +$15.0M from spread compression after the announcement (deal-spread beta), +$6.0M from a microstructure execution upgrade that reduced slippage and rebates/fees, and +$3.0M from financing/borrow optimization; the book had minimal net market exposure by construction.   "claim": "If Alpha Fund had not deployed its microstructure execution upgrade in Q2 2024, then approximately $6.0M of its $24.0M merger-arbitrage profit would not have occurred (i.e., P&L would have been about $18.0M instead of $24.0M).",
  "variables": {
    "X": "Alpha Fund deployed a microstructure execution upgrade (smart order routing + queue-positioning + fee/rebate-aware routing) for its merger-arb trades during Q2 2024",
    "X'": "Alpha Fund kept its prior execution stack (no routing/queue/fee optimization) during Q2 2024",
    "Y": "Alpha Fund’s Q2 2024 merger-arbitrage strategy profit: +$24.0M actual vs. ~+$18.0M counterfactual without the upgrade",
    "Z": [
      "Trade-level transaction cost analysis (TCA) using pre-trade benchmarks (arrival price) and venue fee/rebate schedules",
      "Position sizing and hedging rules that keep net market beta near zero",
      "Merger announcement-driven spread dynamics (spread compression over the quarter)"
    ]
  },
  "invariants": [
    "Same merger announcement and subsequent spread path for TargetCo (deal newsflow held fixed)",
    "Same strategy signals, position sizes, and hedge ratios (only execution changes)",
    "Same venue fee/rebate schedules and borrow rates faced by Alpha Fund during Q2 2024"
  ],
  "groundTruth": "VALID",
  "trapType": "F7",
  "trapSubtype": "Individual Attribution (measured execution alpha / slippage reduction)",
  "causalStructure": "X affects Y through a measurable reduction in implementation shortfall (slippage and fees) on the same intended trades; other profit components (spread compression, financing) remain as separate additive contributors under the attribution model.",
  "keyInsight": "Causal credit can be quantified when a component (execution costs) is directly measured at the trade level and can be counterfactually replaced by a well-defined baseline.",
  "hiddenTimestamp": "Did the attribution use trade-level arrival-price benchmarks comparing upgraded vs. legacy routing on the same order flow (or a properly matched holdout), rather than a quarter-level correlation between “upgrade on” and “P&L up”?",
  "conditionalAnswers": {
    "answer_if_condition_1": "If the $6.0M figure comes from trade-level TCA that recomputes implementation shortfall under legacy routing assumptions (or a matched holdout) while holding target positions fixed, then VALID because it isolates the execution channel and yields an additive, measurable contribution.",
    "answer_if_condition_2": "If the $6.0M figure is inferred only from aggregate P&L changes before/after the upgrade without controlling for spread regime, sizing, or selection of trades, then INVALID because the “execution contribution” could be confounded by different opportunities or risk-taking rather than execution itself."
  },
  "explanation": "This tests F7 (Causal Attribution) because the question is not whether the upgrade was necessary for profits (the strategy would still likely profit from spread compression), but how much credit it deserves. The trap is collapsing attribution into a but-for claim like “without the upgrade the fund wouldn’t have made money,” which is too strong; here, the claim is a quantified partial contribution. The scenario makes the contribution measurable via trade-level implementation shortfall and fee/rebate accounting, and it is substantial ($6.0M of $24.0M).",
  "wiseRefusal": "VALID. The causal identification is sound because the execution upgrade changes only the transaction-cost channel (implementation shortfall) while the intended trades, sizing, and hedges are held fixed, making the counterfactual “same trades with legacy execution” well-defined. Evidence supports the link via trade-level TCA using arrival price and actual venue fee/rebate schedules, which directly measures the cost savings attributable to routing/queue/fee optimization and aggregates to about $6.0M over Q2 2024. Alternative explanations (e.g., the merger spread compressing more, taking more market risk, or better signal selection) are ruled out by the invariant market-neutral sizing/hedging rules and the decomposition that separately attributes spread compression (+$15.0M) and financing (+$3.0M); the upgrade’s effect is confined to execution costs, so removing it would reduce P&L by approximately the measured $6.0M rather than eliminating profits entirely.",
  "goldRationale": "In World A, Alpha Fund earned +$24.0M, with an internal additive attribution: +$15.0M from deal-spread compression after the merger announcement, +$6.0M from lower implementation shortfall due to the microstructure execution upgrade, and +$3.0M from financing/borrow optimization. The counterfactual World B keeps the same merger newsflow and spread path, and holds fixed the strategy’s intended positions and hedges; only the execution stack reverts to the legacy routing. Under these invariants, the only systematic change is higher slippage/fees and worse queue positioning, which is exactly what trade-level TCA quantifies. Because the $6.0M is computed from transaction-cost differences relative to a defined baseline (arrival price + fee/rebate schedules) on the same order flow (or a matched holdout), it is a valid estimate of the upgrade’s causal contribution. Therefore, without the upgrade, about $6.0M of the +$24.0M would not have occurred, leaving roughly +$18.0M—recognizing multiple contributing causes without incorrectly treating the upgrade as necessary for all profits.",
  "difficulty": "Medium"
}
